text: from the British Retail Consortium and I
wanted to take this opportunity to
provide you with an update on the food
supply chain and the steps that we are
all taking to ensure that everyone has
access to the food that they need we
recognize that this is a challenging
time and that there are many things that
the government is asking the nation to
do differently as we work together to
fight this pandemic however there is one
message I want to start with loud and
clear this afternoon which is be
responsible when you shop and think of
others buying more than you need means
that others may be left without and it
is making life more difficult for those
frontline workers such as our doctors
and nurses and NHS support staff who are
working so hard in such difficult
circumstances
so as you shop think of those who are
finishing their late shifts and need to
pop to the local shop at the end of a
long day today the Prime Minister and I
have spoken to the retail sector there
is more than enough food to go around
and our food supply chain is able to
expand production to cope with increased
demand in the last week sales of some
foods have increased significantly and
manufacturers have produced around 50
percent more food than they usually
would there is no shortage of food
available and more is arriving at shops
every day but the challenge that all of
our retailers have faced is keeping
shelf stopped throughout the day in the
face of increased purchasing behavior we
all have a role to play in ensuring that
we come through this together so the
government has taken steps to set aside
rules restricting delivery to stores and
relaxed restrictions on government
govern our 's so that more Goods can be
delivered to every store every day and
we have also set aside competition laws
so that supermarkets can coordinate
their efforts locally sharing staff
sharing delivery vehicles and
coordinating their store opening times
to ensure that food reaches every part
of the country
we've also waved the plastic bag charge
and on Ahnold for online purchases to
speed up deliveries our retailers and
food producers who supply them are
working around the clock to keep shelf
stocked and the nation fed supermarkets
are recruiting more staff protecting
shopping time for older and vulnerable
people and limiting shopping hours so
they have more time to restock and I
want to take this opportunity to thank
all those staff working in our
supermarkets and food businesses up and
down the country today who are doing so
much to deliver such a crucial service
to us all but as the Prime Minister has
said many times we need every citizen of
this country to play their part - some
supermarkets have put in place purchase
limits on some items to ensure that
there is fair trading and that their
shelves remain stopped for longer
everyone must respect such measures and
respect the staff working in these shops
who are doing their best to ensure that
both you and your neighbors get the food
supplies that you need thank you I'd
like to pass over to Helen no thank you
thank you I'm just to pick up on a
couple of points there firstly I mean
you don't need you don't need me to tell
you about the the sort of levels of
unprecedented demand that we've all seen
and I really wanted to reassure
everybody that people right across the
food industry from growers packers
producers distributors drivers and the
people right at the front line in our
stores are doing everything they can to
make sure that we have the food food
that we all need and it's almost like
we're seeing basically a peak in demand
like Christmas without the four month
buildup in in planning that you would
normally have in advance and we've been
able to do that in two weeks there is
plenty of food in the supply chain the
issue is around people and lorries so
getting that food right into the front
line onto our shelves which is why we've
seen shortages in some areas across
across lots of different different lines
in different at different areas of the
country what's been vital over the last
few days is the dialogue that we've had
with government they've really listened
carefully to the things that people
across the industry have highlight
that would make it easier to to increase
capacity they've the there the key is I
guess not just that listening but being
able to act quickly and and Jorge is
highlighted there a couple of things I
mean for example lifting curfew hours
for deliveries has enabled much more
lorries to get through the supply chain
and into stores more quickly and there's
a whole list of things where we've
raised an issue and it's been addressed
quickly and I think that is going to be
vital as we go forward over the over the
coming few weeks and I think the you
know the food retailers that I'm talking
to every on every day and on the call
with the Prime Minister earlier really
wanted to undermine underline that
message about you know in in encouraging
everybody to really be considerate in
what they buy make sure that they only
buy what they need there is there is a
billion pounds more food in people's
houses than there was three weeks ago so
we should make sure we we eat some of it
and be considerate and also think about
other people right across your
communities and how we can all help them
in making sure that they can pick up and
get their shopping and so I think it's
much more about how we all work together
to to rise to the challenges that we're
facing Thank You Helen and thank you so
I would just like to make a plea on
behalf of all my colleagues in the NHS
nurses doctors paramedics and many many
others who are working incredibly hard
at the moment to manage this outbreak of
coronavirus are now preparing for the
surge that they know will be coming at
them it's incredibly important that they
to have access to food to those
essential supplies that they need I'm
sure many of you will have seen a video
posted on social media yesterday by Dawn
a critical care nurse who was in tears
at the end of a long shift because she
could not get access to the supplies
that she needed and and frankly we
should all be ashamed but that has to
happen it's unacceptable these are the
very people that we will all need
to look after perhaps us or our loved
ones in the weeks ahead it's critical
that by not stockpiling by not selfishly
shopping by leaving those supplies for
others to but our health workers are
able to get access to to what they need
to these are the people that we will all
be relying on more than we ever have
done in the weeks ahead thanks very much
and Secretary of State many of the pleas
that we made so far have fallen on deaf
ears is the government prepared to at
some point intervene and perhaps
introduce compulsory limits on what
people can buy and a supplemental
questionnaire for me many people will be
open about today for a walk with the
families and we'll see parks absolutely
packed with other people is that safe
and should people be taking further
measures to distance from others in
public spaces I'll answer the first
point it may refer to Stephen on the
second the reality is that most of the
supermarkets are already of their own
accord and they they've discussed this
putting limits on certain items so I
don't think it is necessary or
appropriate for the government to to
take this different stores on different
items are working together to identify
what an appropriate limit is today I'm
asking everybody to respect what those
supermarkets are doing they are trying
to ensure that their shelves don't go
empty early in the morning and to do
that and achieve that they are putting
item limits for certain goods and it's
very important that everybody respects
that more food is arriving every day
there's no shortage of food production
the crucial thing is that we need people
to come down and buy only what they need
and to think of others when they are
purchasing John
thank you John Craig is quite skynews

the truth is that there's already been a

the the biggest increase in demand is

there's a range of symptoms the two

should it's incredibly important that

equipped equipment that staff should
take and of course that is what will

coronavirus and just just coming back to

customers have operations right across

know significant announcements like the
one that was made yesterday by the Prime

for example is that that demand is
spikes again after the announcement but
then now is beginning to actually trail

that's what we're going to see here as
well in terms of trends cars inning

so a request on the mo D for deliveries
no but we we are obviously giving
increasingly thought within government
to how we will protect those who may be

vulnerable
and I know that more will be said about

about treatment choices and frankly our

so on your first point as I said earlier
all of the major retailers are working
together in exercising their own

to put limits item limits on certain
certain certain issues so toilet roll is

really understood there was a big spike

an item where to ensure the goods

supermarket's together took a position
of putting an item limit I think it is

those who are concerned once they have

and when that happens then the retailers

in competition or I think has given the
the forum to be able to have the

what's happens it's so far is that
individual businesses have really looked

the interactions that they have with

develop strategy
is to suppress and to reduce the virus
different countries take slightly

the fewer people who are infected the

the less the pressure on health services
so the advice in this country which is

and I'll go back to what I said earlier
that's why it is absolutely crucial that

we don't think there is a there's a risk

have is getting food
to the shelves and keeping it there
which is why the supermarkets have taken
